I picked pecans in south east Texas when I was a kid just like my parents , and brothers and everyone else in that part of the country . it still is a very labor intensive job . this show gives a very unrealistic view of what actually happens harvesting pecans . you are on your hands and knees all day long in sometimes freezing temperatures picking them by hand from among the tall grass and fallen leaves under the trees so no gloves are worn . what is shown here is a very large , rich plantation Co hybrid pecans that in no way resemble the crop that gives the best flavor for candies and pies .

China is where pecans are manufactured. They shred old motorcycle tires, add plastic rice bits, blend in ground shrimp shells and tails, then inject the paste into silicone molds that look like pecans. They initial cook them over sewage treatment plant methane gas. Then they are airbrushed with artificial tanning solution while they final dry in the street behind the shop.

In the USA, we don't manufacture them. We grow them on real pecan trees then process them for sale to various markets.
